questions.question: Who is considered father of modern computing?
questions.explanation: Alan Turing: mathematician, logician, pioneer. Turing machine: theoretical model of computation. Turing Test: measures machine intelligence. Code-breaking: Enigma during WWII. Legacy: computer science foundation. AI: named after him (Turing Test). Impact: revolutionary thinker.

questions.question: What was the first general-purpose electronic computer?
questions.explanation: ENIAC: Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer (1946). Size: room-filling (1,800 sq ft). Weight: 30 tons. Power: 150 kilowatts. Speed: 5,000 additions/second. Programming: manual wiring, punch cards. Limitation: no stored program. Impact: demonstrated electronic computation.

questions.question: What era introduced microprocessors?
questions.explanation: 1970s: microprocessor revolution. Intel 4004: first commercial microprocessor (1971). 8-bit era: 8008, 8080, 6502. Personal computers: Apple II, Commodore, IBM PC. Software: BASIC language, operating systems. Industry: birth of tech giants. Accessibility: computing becomes personal.

questions.question: What was the first commercially successful personal computer?
questions.explanation: Apple II: released 1977. Designer: Steve Jobs, Steve Wozniak. Price: affordable ($1,298). Built-in: keyboard, power supply, monitor connector. Software: VisiCalc (first spreadsheet). Impact: home computing mainstream. Legacy: standardized personal computer. Sales: over 5 million units.

questions.question: When was the IBM Personal Computer released?
questions.explanation: IBM PC: released August 1981. Impact: corporate computing legitimacy. Processor: Intel 8088. OS: MS-DOS (Microsoft). Open architecture: clones emerged. Legacy: dominated business computing. Market: became industry standard. Competitors: IBM-compatible became generic term.

questions.question: What operating system revolutionized user interfaces?
questions.explanation: GUI: replaced command-line interfaces. Macintosh: pioneered commercial GUI (1984). Windows: Microsoft's answer (1985+). Elements: windows, icons, menus, pointers. Accessibility: non-technical users enabled. Adoption: mainstream computing transition. Impact: modern computing looks similar.

questions.question: What network connected early computers?
questions.explanation: ARPANET: military research network (1969). Purpose: surviving nuclear war communications. Decentralized: no central control. Packet switching: data routing. Legacy: internet foundation. Expansion: universities, eventually public. Impact: revolutionized communication.

questions.question: What sparked the personal computer revolution?
questions.explanation: Transistor: replaced vacuum tubes (1947). Advantages: smaller, cheaper, less heat, more reliable. Transistor radios: first consumer products. Integrated circuits: multiple transistors on chip. Moore's Law: transistor count doubling. Impact: enabled miniaturization, computation portable.

questions.question: What was the first programming language?
questions.explanation: Assembly: first programming language. Before: manual machine code (binary, tedious). Mnemonics: human-readable instructions (ADD, MOV). Assembler: translates to machine code. Limitation: machine-specific. Portability: none. Legacy: low-level, efficient. Still used: embedded systems, performance-critical.

questions.question: What decade saw the rise of the internet?
questions.explanation: 1990s: internet commercialization. World Wide Web: invented (1989), became mainstream. Browsers: Netscape Navigator (1994), Internet Explorer. Dot-com boom: venture capital surge. E-commerce: Amazon (1994), eBay (1995). Bubble: burst 2000. Legacy: web fundamental today.
